content.description: Same start as How Good is Your Pull-Out Game but instead of topping out trend leftward on small, sharp holds with big moves and terrible feet to the end of the boulder, then top out with more ease. A couple of the holds are sharp and its a bit contrived but there is some funky-fun movement if you can figure it out [the route name has a beta hint for the top-out ;)]
content.location: extension of How Good is Your Pull-Out Game?

content.description: Start low on the crimpy-crack holds. Go left to the weird vertical sloper-rail and slap up to a deadpoint to a good two finger pocket and top out.
content.protection: pad and spotter to push you off the tree
content.location: Find the part of the rock by the tree.

content.description: On overhanging face it the obvious crack going up the boulder.
content.protection: pad and spotter due to close proximity of a tree

content.description: Get silly low on jugs to the left of the start of Spider Crack and make one big move into the starting hold of the crack and finish up it.

climbs.name: How Good is Your Pull-Out Game?

content.description: Not sure about the grade please feel free to comment on that. start with both hands and heel on the low crimp and fire up to small crimps trending left with limited feet. Hit the good flake at the top of the boulder and dyno out left to a sloping rail. Mantle to top out.
content.location: left side of the boulder. I will get photos for beta purposes in the near future on here.

climbs.name: The Dumbest Line I've Ever Done

content.description: There is a rocky outcrop behind the left face. It is overhanging. I got bored and traversed it. Figured I'd put it here but really a time waster.
content.protection: none unless you try it in which case a crashpad will suffice

content.description: Great crack warm-up along the side face. It's pretty obvious just climb it until it ends and top out.
A line up the arete on the left side of the overhanging portion. The ultra-tempting feet around the corner are off-limits if you want the V1 tick. V0 if you use them.

Single boulder off of Diamond Lake Road along the Shenipsit Trail in Glastonbury. It is the part of the trail connecting Imperial Drive to Diamond Lake Road.  

  No mas Wiley Coyote and gang. All is confirmed clear.
